key_points: On October 4, a misconfiguration during routine maintenance caused a global outage of Facebook, WhatsApp, Instagram, and Messenger for over 6 hours, affecting nearly 2.9 billion users.
The outage was the result of a faulty configuration change on Facebook's backbone routers which manage traffic between its data centers.
An incorrect command aimed to check capacity inadvertently disabled Facebook's border gateway protocol (BGP) routers, cutting off the data centers from the internet.
A bug in an audit tool failed to catch the mistake, which allowed it to be deployed across Facebook's entire network environment.
With the BGP routers offline, Facebook's DNS servers couldn't translate domain names into IP addresses, causing users to be unable to access its sites.
Gartner predicts that through 2023, 99% of firewall breaches will be due to misconfigurations, not the firewalls themselves.
Human error, amplified by complex environments, is a leading cause of network and service outages.
The article highlights the vulnerability of network environments to misconfigurations, potentially leading to major security breaches.
The 2019 Capital One data breach, impacting over 100 million customers, was caused by a misconfigured firewall.
FireMon offers tools for managing network security policies and minimizing misconfigurations that could compromise network security.
